Q: What is the name of Ishmael’s close companion aboard the Pequod?
A:
Queequeg.
Sources: chunk 929, chunk 575, chunk 662, chunk 660 (Moby Dick; Or, The Whale).

“Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg.”
“Well, bring him along then.”
And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that I
had done a good morning’s work, and that the Pequod was the identical
ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round the Cape.

the grindstone. That’s he; thank ye, Bildad. Now then, my young man,

“Captain Peleg,” said I, “I have a friend with me who wants to ship
too—shall I bring him down to-morrow?”
“To be sure,” said Peleg. “Fetch him along, and we’ll look at him.”

Metrics.R: The score is 0.26 because most retrieved snippets are irrelevant — e.g. 'Yojo purposed befriending us', 'had already pitched upon a vessel', 'I, Ishmael, should infallibly light upon' — none name the companion. However, the few relevant lines do identify him: 'First of all was Queequeg', 'Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had selected', and 'there generally subsists between the two, a close intimacy and friendliness', which point to Queequeg as Ishmael’s close companion.
